description: From Middle English peyne, payne, from Old French and Anglo-Norman peine, paine, from Latin poena (“punishment, pain”), from Ancient Greek ποινή (poinḗ, “bloodmoney, weregild, fine, price paid, penalty”).
Compare Danish pine, Norwegian Bokmål pine, German Pein, Dutch pijn, Afrikaans pyn. See also pine (the verb). Partly displaced native Old English sār (whence Modern English sore).

entries.meaning: (countable and uncountable) An ache or bodily suffering, or an instance of this; an unpleasant sensation, resulting from a derangement of functions, disease, or injury by violence; hurt.
(uncountable) The condition or fact of suffering or anguish especially mental, as opposed to pleasure; torment; distress
(countable, from pain in the neck) An annoying person or thing.
(uncountable, dated) Suffering inflicted as punishment or penalty.
(chiefly in the plural) Labour; effort; great care or trouble taken in doing something.
(countable and uncountable) An ache or bodily suffering, or an instance of this; an unpleasant sensation, resulting from a derangement of functions, disease, or injury by violence; hurt.
examples: The greatest difficulty lies in treating patients with chronic pain.
I had to stop running when I started getting pains in my feet.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The condition or fact of suffering or anguish especially mental, as opposed to pleasure; torment; distress
examples: In the final analysis, pain is a fact of life.
The pain of departure was difficult to bear.

entries.meaning: (countable, from pain in the neck) An annoying person or thing.
examples: Your mother is a right pain.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, dated) Suffering inflicted as punishment or penalty.
examples: You may not leave this room on pain of death.

entries.meaning: (chiefly in the plural) Labour; effort; great care or trouble taken in doing something.

verbs.description: pain (third-person singular simple present pains, present participle paining, simple past and past participle pained)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To hurt; to put to bodily uneasiness or anguish; to afflict with uneasy sensations of any degree of intensity; to torment; to torture.
(transitive) To render uneasy in mind; to disquiet; to distress; to grieve.
examples: It pains me to say that I must let you go.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To inflict suffering upon as a penalty; to punish.
(intransitive, India) To feel pain; to hurt.
examples: Please help me, I am paining hard.

description: From Middle English payn (“a kind of pie with a soft crust”), from Old French pain (“bread”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete, cooking) Any of various breads stuffed with a filling.
